												Well, er. Boxing fans don't exactly have a whole lot to choose from when it comes to Steam games, do they? The truth is, until the Fight Night series makes its way to Steam, this is the best we're going to get. The unfortunate thing is that the "best" isn't really that good. GameplayThe game plays very similarly to a dumbed-down version of... You guessed it - Fight Night. Fighter movement is controlled with the left stick whilst the punches are mapped to directions on the right stick, or alternatively the face buttons. Left and right shoulder buttons are used for the high-low modifier and block, respectively, whilst tapping the right shoulder button lightly allows for a dodge. Both you and your opponent have a health and a stamina bar. Big punches such as uppercuts do more damage but drain more stamina, whilst jabs … You get the drift. Dodging a punch successfully results in a Matrix-like slowdown that allows you to get a solid counter-hit in for extra damage and less stamina. The fight goes on until one person knows the other person down and they stay down for a full 10 seconds, or a decision is reached at the end of however many rounds you set it to. It’s the bare bones for any game that tries to call itself a boxing simulator, although the aforementioned issues prevent it from really being a good game.  Poor dodging system - Real Boxing only allows you to dodge in a single direction (i.e. you cannot influence the direction you’re dodging), so the only thing that’s required of the player is timing. The problem is that the dodge comes out so slowly that you literally have to press it before the opponent’s attack comes out. It turns the skill/reflex-intensive dodging system of Fight Night and turns it into a skill-less guessing game  Poor high-low system – Since there’s no high-low blocking system, holding the block button will block both high and low attacks. What’s worse, unlike Fight Night, where punching the head does more damage whilst punching to the body does less damage but drains more stamina from the opponent (the so-called “money in the bank” approach in boxing), Real Boxing makes no such distinction. It’s almost pointless that they bothered to include body punches at all in this game.  Button-mashing - You can get through the entire game with button mashing. At no point in the game did I feel that throwing one particular punch was more effective than throwing any other. I beat the first opponent in the game the same way I beat the last opponent – mashing.  Shallow career mode – Literally has you fight one opponent after another, earning cash whilst buying upgrades. Rinse and repeat until you become the supreme champion of the universe or some ♥♥♥♥. Every so often you’re allowed to do a “training mini-game” in order to increase your stats as well. Speaking of which…  Tedious mini-games - There are 3 training mini-games, each improving a separate stat (strength, stamina and speed). Unfortunately, all three are essentially glorified quick-time events, and very easy. It’s incredibly repetitive and tedious, but necessary in order to improve your boxer’s stats  Poor multiplayer implementation – Purely online matchmaking. No local multiplayer or even the ability to host a game against a friend. I can’t comment further because quite frankly I never got a game going.Overall, the issue is that the game boils down to a skill-independent, button-mashing affair. I’ve figured out the secret to the game. You ready?If opponent has worse stats than you – Mash anything. You can’t lose.If opponent has equal or better stats than you – Hold block. Wait for opponent to drain his stamina, then mash anything. Rinse, repeat.PresentationI have to admit that the game does look quite pretty for an indie title. Character models look realistic, even if the models are fairly bland. Supports 1920x1080 resolution, which is nice. Sound effects are adequate. Sadly lacks any real music outside of the nauseating entrance music that plays when your boxer walks towards the ring. A single commentator is present for the game, and whilst it’s a nice touch, he appears to only have approximately 10 lines and uses them all at the wrong time. Be prepared as he calls every one of your uppercuts a jab and a complete one-sided pounding as the “Fight of the decade”. Overall ImpressionI’m an indie gamer at heart. Because of that, I hate games like this. I hate that games like this exist because it’s an example of an indie game making a strictly inferior version of a AAA game like Fight Night and dumbing down all the mechanics and depth whilst hiding behind the fact that it’s an “indie” game. Indie games should never, ever be strict downgrades of AAA games. Unfortunately, as I said before, us Steam gamers looking for a chance to practice the art of the sweet science aren’t exactly spoilt for choice. This is the best boxing game on Steam right now, and if that’s what you’re looking for then I would recommend you give it a shot. For everyone else though, stay away.

												Do not be put off by all the negative reviews comparing this game to Electronic Art's Fight Night series of games. Fight Night is a AAA Sports title created by a developer who has a long history of developing boxing games, and it costed 6-times as much as this game. Of course Fight night going to be better, but that does not mean Real Boxing is not an enjoyable game worth it's $10 price tag.Real Boxing Is more arcade than simulation, and there is not a lot of depth, but the action is fast paced and the multiplayer mode should be entertaining for hardcore boxing fans, at least in short spurts.  The single player career mode is basic, and there are not all that many different characters to fight against, but the mode exists. There are options for editing the appearance of your boxer, but you do not seem to be able to edit your boxer's name, which is a little bit annoying.Aside from that, there are also the standard training mini games that you would expect to see in a boxing game. These mini games require you to press the right-stick in a certain direction in time with the on-screen cues. As you might guess the mini games become repetitive very quickly (but so did the mini games in fight Night).The in-ring boxing action is not very simulation-like, but it's not exactly the mindless button-masher other reviews make it out to be.  You can throw all the punches you would expect (using either an anolog stick or the buttons) but there is no option for using dirty tactics such as headbutts or low blows. You can grab and clinch your opponent, but only when your energy drops below a certain level. Blocking is done with a single button, and it automatically blocks head or body shots as needed. You can also use a perfectly timed press of the block button to slip an opponents punch, creating a slow-motion effect allowing you an extra moment to throw a counter punch. There is no bobbing/weaving. There is no way to take a knee if your getting pummled, and there is no option for switching from orthodox to southpaw stance.Pros:- Fast paced action with easy to pick-up controls- Decent looking graphics and presentation for a budget title- Online multiplayer boxing matches- Commentary is repetitive but sounds good for an arcade boxing experience- it's the only (somewhat realistic) boxing game on SteamCons:- Boxer movement/footwork is not very smooth- Small roster of characters - No real world boxers- Short/uninspired single-player career mode- No matchmaking options for the online multiplayer modeThe bottom line is that it's not exactly a great game, but it's the best boxing game I have on my PC. The game will not have much appeal for most gamers, but hardcore boxing fans will probably find it fun being able to swap leather with other players now and then. It's not Fight Night Champion, but it's actually better than I had expected it to be.

												I'm torn on how to review this game.If I consider it as arcade-ey, it's absolutely passable.  I might even recommend it to a friend who is into the sweet science.  If, however, I consider it as a boxing sim (which I think is how it's trying to present itself, given the title and promo material), it falls far short.While the graphics are decent, that's about it.  There just isn't much to this game.There are three "tournaments" which will give you completion and credits.  Credits can be used to purchase some upgrades (not many -- think "lower the stamina cost of your jab").  You can also play training minigames once every five fights to gain a few points in each of the three (just 3) main skill categories.  If you fight above your ratings, you'll be slaughtered.  If you fight below, you'll be doing the slaughtering.As for the fights, again, there's a good deal of what I'd consider necessities for a sim completely absent.Blocking is all-or-nothing -- if you block, you'll block all punches, regardless of where they're aimed.  No covering your midsection at the expense of your face, no getting your hands up and leaving your body exposed.  Which, I should mention, isn't a huge problem, as there's no practical difference in where punches land.  An uppercut to the midsection is equally as damaging as an uppercut to the chin, and neither will have any long-term bearing on the fight (e.g. no laying into body shots at the beginning of a fight to wear out an opponent).Though the scorecard shown at the end of a fight has 12 rounds listed, fights always last 3.  Rounds are 1 minute long.All in all, if you're looking for what's essentially PunchOut with a less interesting cast of characters and improved graphics, this is probably worth your time.  If you're looking for a sim, trying to be light like a butterfly and sting like a bee, applying that sweet science all over your opponent's face, look elsewhere.4 DQs (afaik impossible in this game) / 10 TKOs (afaik impossible in this game)

												As a pugilism game, Real Boxing exists in a category all its own, and not in a good way. It isn't realistic enough to pass as a sports career simulator, nor is it fake enough to pass as a Punch Out! clone.Boxer customization is limited to the same two character models (tall troglodyte or small Asian) with varying skin tones, hair styles and tattoos. You can buy your character different gloves and shorts, but they're expensive and with little variety. Facial animation are so limited that you can barely tell apart the winner of a match from the loser. The round card girls range from a dead-eyed blonde to a dead-eyed brunette. The training mini-games are uninspired run-of-the-mill rhythm challenges sans the music. The fighting physics are rough, with knockout animations totally unrelated to the type of punch that provoked them. When more effort is put into the bosom-giggle physics of the girls than the fights themselves, you know you're in trouble.There are some good details in Real Boxing. Its fight mechanics are very easy to learn. The ring environments look very good. Career Mode is limited to only 27 fights in 3 categories, so at least it's a very short commitment. And you can't beat the price. All of Real Boxing's many defects would be forgiven if at least the game was fun.Vivid Games seems to be doing well with this franchise on mobile platforms by doing a Rocky tie-in. I wish them well. I believe eventually they will make a great boxing game, but Real Boxing isn't it.

												The fact that this is a handheld/mobile port is frighteningly obvious. While there is a lack of boxing games on PC, this game is not up to standard. The animations are very poor and the gameplay is poorly thought out. Career mode is very skinny with three mini-games that you can only occasionally use to train your boxer, and the title fights are insanely easy on the first circuit and insanely hard on the second circuit. Progression is really repeatiing the same low-level circuit until you can get enough cash to boost your stats to survive getting hit in the next level.The fighting mechanics lack any flow or depth. You cannot throw combinations, so boxing is simply a matter of tapping the jab or hook button. Blocking is a one-button affair, and while you can punch through a block, you don't have enough stamina to exploit it. Hit reactions are awkward - punches don't connect to the opponent, so if the opponent is staggering, your punches are sure to miss, which is very unintuitive. The counterattack system seems like something nice, but it's really just an opportunistic slow-mo which is botched by the lack of fluid fighting.The characters are all the same. There are no distinctions between boxing styles, so it's really just a slugfest. It's disappointing to see a "Real Boxing" title feature nothing that makes boxing real.Some other huge flaws:* Clinch mini-game has no timer. You can clinch for the entire round.* Getting up from a KO immediately goes into the fight, allowing the opponent free hits before your controls are live.* No three-knockdown rule. The AI is generally unable to come back and gets knocked down right away, but there is no way to win by TKO.In a nutshell, winning the game is merely based on when the AI "forgets" to block rather than any tactical gameplay.

												"Down goes Real Boxing, down goes Real Boxing!" 5/10I'm not sure why, but whenever I find out that a PC game is just some lame mobile port, I'm not too happy about it. Actually I do know why; buying a mobile game for the PC makes me feel gypped, hustled, ripped off, like I paid real money for some fake game made for lesser devices. Like someone took my hard earned money right out of my pocket when I wasn't looking. Like a thief, a con-man, a low-life would do! Needless to say, I don't think too much about mobile gaming, at the moment at least. And in case you haven't guessed it yet, this game is in fact a mobile port.The majority of mobile games I've played felt incredibly easy, most likely to account for the fact that they're meant to be played on a touch screen without a physical controller. And this game is no different. Which is a bit upsetting for me to admit actually, because at first glance this game comes off as a pretty solid boxing simulator that I never would have guessed originated on smartphones. But after playing it for a few hours I quickly realized how bad of a game it really is, and how clearly meant for smartphones it initially was. Basically all you have to do is lose a handful of matches, level your player up, then never lose again. Because the only difficulty in this game comes from having a weak player. After his levels raise, your opponent's weaknesses become blatantly apparent and all you need to do from there is blindly punch and jab your way to the top. Seriously, all you need are your right and left jabs and nothing else. The game is seriously that easy.Aside from the simplicity of the game, there are still plenty of other reasons to avoid this game like a week old gas station breakfast burrito. For starters, after you complete the incredibly short career mode there really isn't anything else to do, and the game doesn't even try to give you any kind of incentive to keep playing. Typical mobile game. Also, the announcer has about twenty things he says in total and you'll grow tired of them all within an hour. Typical mobile game. The intros are the same for every match, the controls are good but could be better, and there is barely any variety of places to fight. The only thing that may be redeeming about this game is the online play, but I never got into that because I was too discouraged by the single player experience. At least I got this game in a cheap bundle for a few bucks. And for that I'm grateful.

												TL:DR - Not a boxing sim, but an arcade beat-'em-up. 6/10'Real Boxing' is exactly the opposite of what it says on the tin. This is not, in any way, shape, or form, a real boxing game.First things first, the game doesn't help itself by having a shoddy set up. The game defaults of medium graphical settings regardless of your rig when you first start the game. Do yourself a favour, ignore the people moaning on the forums, go into the settings, set everything to max and switch blood on, then restart the game. The game looks at least on par with Fight Night Champion, possibly better, though it's hard to tell as this has a more cartoony aesthetic that makes a direct comparison difficult. For a budget title, the graphics are more than adequte.It doesn't help that this was obviously put together by people with no real knowledge of boxing. A 'right jab' is not a jab, it's a straight cross. Common terminology here people.So, the boxing itself. This game stinks of 'gotta match budget Fight Night' all the way through;Training mini-games? Check, but they're ripped straight out of a late 90's early 00's copy Dance Dance Revolution and require you to press the right button when it flashes green in a box, at the right rhythm. The training teaches you absolutely nothing useful for in the game, it's bashing buttons to increase your stats.AI that struggles to overcome a simple jab-jab-straight combination? Check, with the added bonus of having an AI that only seems to throw Hooks/Uppercuts, it's easy to play an outside fighter and jab them to death. Speaking of styles... Even less of a distinction between the styles than Fight Night has. No stances, no punch styles, as far as i'm aware no southpaws, no footwork, no leaning beyond a rudimentary 'press button to dodge'.Unlimited hold button to block? Check. Slightly better than Fight Night in that 3 punches will break the block, ruined by the fact the canned stagger animation ALWAYS takes them out of the range of any of your punches, meaning breaking the block is essentially worthless. Speaking of animations...Animations are horrible. Knockouts could have come from Knockout Kings on the old N64, no physics, no impact, just a guy falling over like a tree. Tiiiiimbeeeeeeer!Canned, nonsensical commentary? Check! My guy has not won the title, it was a standard tournament match with nothing on the line. 4 jabs in a row is NOT a 'tricky combination', a straight cross is NOT a 'nice jab'.Bad blood effects? Check! After the bad blood developed in the Fight Night community after EA rebalanced the blood effects with the bare knuckle DLC, this game looks like it's been made by a group of 15 year olds who think every boxing match should have arterial blood sprays coming from every hook. The ring gets spattered with bright red blood, dripping from each fighter by the end of the first round. Speaking of damage....There is no inter-round mechanics. No trainer tips, no swelling/cut management, no punch stats. Your health is auto-healed between rounds and you have no real idea of how you're doing, as there are no colour commentator scoring cards.There is also no referee. This means no fouls, no point deductions, unlimited clinches, no rabbit punching, etc. The clinches are especially annoying, as there is no end if you and the AI are evenly matched. It's another pointless minigame.There are some pros for the game however. Punch stats are generally realistic, as your fighter will be winded after throwing 4-5 punches that land, or missing 1-2 punches. This leaves a realistic rhythm of jab-jab-hook/cross/uppercut before backing off again and finding a new angle. This is however ruined by the lack of footwork etc. meantioned above. It is also ruined by the fact that Stamina is permanent and non-degrading. This means body shots have no value whatsoever. It also elaves something to be desired when you're pushing for a KO, as there is no way to keep up real sustained pressure.Overall, this is an above average game. It's very reasonably prices, it looks and sounds fine, while the gameplay has been made by people with no real understanding of boxing. Treat it as a arena based quick beat-em-up, with 3, 1 minute rounds, and it's passable.Better yet, download an emulator and play Fight Night Champion.6/10.Edit: Upon completing the game, several achievements did not unlock. 3/10 if they don't sort this basic functionality out.

												I have beaten the game and brought a character up to full stats in close to 6 hours. The game starts as 3 1-minute rounds. This should be a good indication of how good of a simulation it is. If you are going to play it, be sure to adjust the round and time totals and also turn on the blood. I would highly reccomend playing with a contoller. I found the keyboard controls to be nearly unplayable. Even with a controller, the controls were sluggish and occasionally unresponsive. The mechanics of the game are pretty basic. You have a health bar and a stamina bar. The stamina bar determines the strength of your punches. It is short and regenerates quickly. Your health determines how many hits you can withstand before getting knocked down. There is a block and it will block any three consecutive punches where it will then break and place you in a stunned animation. The sway mechanic is a joke. You tap the block button when you see a punch coming for your head and if you timed it right, time will slow and give you a chance to swing back with bonus strength. However, there is little rhyme or reason to it it seems. There will be times when they "dodge" the punch but your arm crumples up against their head after connecting with  their character model. When you get low on health you are allowed access to clinching up to regain health. This is a button mash game which starts off easy but becomes quite difficult against later opponents. Standing up from a knockdown is played the same way but the difficutly picks up after the 2nd time you go down.There are only 3 stats in the game. Strength is for damage. Stamina is for your health and stamina bars. Speed is for the speed of your punches and how fast you walk around. You upgrade them through minigames that you gain access to every 5 fights. They aren't very enjoyable. Minigames is the right way to go but they made them feel more like a chore than a way to make your guy stronger. Thankfully you end up buying most of your stats instead of playing those games. You can pick two perks for your fighter out of 8 or so. They can make your punches cost less stamina or help you in the button mash clinch/standup games. While your characters stats feel like they don't matter, having a strength 5 points above their stamina will give you incredible amounts of damage. Strength feels like very much the most useful stat, especially early.Pros-It is a boxing game on PCCons-The mechanics are bad-Character customization is lackluster at best-This is not a boxing simulation game

												* Please note my review is based on the single player career mode only and not online play.After 3 hours played, I have to sadly give this game a negative review.Without any regret, I placed this title on my list of "completed games", where it was promptly uninstalled, despite me not finishing the game. This can only mean that the game was so flawed that there was nothing I could do but give it a miss and not feel guilty that it was being put on the backburner...permanently. Why? Initially I had trouble understanding how the game worked because I don't really watch boxing, nor do I ever play it in real life or in the virtual World, even though I personaly have thrown a punch or two during a pub crawl. So because I only knew the basics of boxing, it should really have meant that I would struggle in a game happily named "Real Boxing", but alas here is where I ran into quite a big problem. Since I was a huge novice, as expected I lost my first two matches because I was doing what I thought was "real" boxing. That was to try and "mix it up" and jab a couple of times, then try a much more potent move, wowing the crowd with a powerful KO. Instead every match seemed rather tame and while they were close affairs, I could not buy a win and quite honestly things were going as expected. During my first three career matches, I had lost two games on points and the last had ended as a draw but things were about to change...drastically. In the game I got myself a draw, I noticed I didn't have to throw so many varied punches, but just throw one particular punch, a jab - then back off a little to recover my stamina. It was a cue that I would definitely bring into my upcoming fourth match where I decided to roll with this uninspring but effecive style of boxing and went back to the ring seeking revenge with my new jabbing prowess... In my fourth match all I threw were jabs, and did so with devastating results. I got the combo count to about 3 or 4 then as my stamina wore down, I backed off and let it recover and then I just went back in and hit left and right handed jabs again and again. After each round I had landed about 40 to 60 punches and my adversary had a mere 5 to 15 each time. At the end of the match, I had a resounding unanimous victory.I then went to the gym and put all my winnings into my boxers speed and also completed the mini games which were available. After 4 matches my speed was something around 70 and by 3 hours played, it had hit the 80 mark. I had a quick footed boxer, with fleeting punches ready to lightly jab into any boxers face as if he were putting on powder with a puffy makeup brush. It was a heavily feminine style of play, but it was effective - and I was tempted to call my boxer Blue Steel.I won every single match with complete ease, all the way to the title belt! Yes you read that right...! Even though I started with two defeats and a draw, I won match after match thereafter to become the champion. So I went up a division and again put all my coins into speed and again with the same boxing style I won fight after fight all the way until I hit the uninstall button on the game.This game has a lot of fighting mechanics, but you don't need any of them. You don't need uppercuts, haymakers, strength, perks, hugging or whatever it is called when you take a nap on the other boxer, etc etc etc.You just jab and run away, and inevitably win - which some how reminded me of World of Warcraft back in 2006 when I used to "dot and run" with my Warlock. If you don't know what that means, then you know exactly how I felt when I first started playing this game - clueless. Yet at the end you feel like a champion and it's not because you are good, it is because the game is completely flawed.Rather than kid myself that I indeed was a "real" boxer, I inevitably preferred to uninstall the game. I knew I was nothing but a jabbing phoney and I just could not bring myself to win the career mode knowing that.  Who want's to be the Lance Armstrong of boxing?I know I didn't. I give this game an F, or 2 out of 10.

												I don't do many reviews, but I feel that this game is getting a lot of undesvered and unwarranted hate.Let me just go ahead and say that this is not Fight Night. If you go into the game trying to compare it to that, you'll be disapointed to say the least. But, if you go into it looking for a game where you can waste a few hours every now and then beating on peoples faces, you'll quite enjoy this. This is a mobile port, but I was surprised to see that it's not your crappy run of the mill port that you usually get. The graphics are decent, not mind blowing, the controls are very responsive, and it just feels good when you land hits on the AI. There is a career mode where you can create your own character and fight various other fighters in a bracket for a belt. Leveling up your character is quite fun. The more fights you win, the more points you get to help level up your character. You can even buy perks for your character to get more of an advantage. The fights do sometimes come down to button mashing, but there are also tactics involved in being proficient at the game.There is also multiplayer. I've played a couple matches and it's great so far. I got my butt kicked in both, but I admit that it was a fun experience. There was hardly any lag and I connected immediately when another person was found. I was surprised that the multiplayer even worked considering how some of the big AAA titles that get ported to PC can't even get their multiplayer to function properly.Now, are there things that this game can improve on? Yes, of course. Many. Camera animations, voice acting, more mini games to help boost your characters stats, better character customization, and just overall a lot more content can be added to the game. But, if the devs continue to improve upon this game, it can turn out to be something truly fantastic.Edit: Yes, you can play against your friends in multiplayer. They just have to be ready to accept the invite quickly. I expect that to be fixed very soon though.

												I was looking for a half-way decent boxing sim when I saw this on STEAM. There is a sever lack of good boxing games on STEAM and for $5.00 I figured I'd give this one a go. While the game looks like the developers made an attempt at making the game look graphically beautiful games, there's things that bother me about the game. Like the slack jawed, blank eyedexpression every character in the game appears to have. The game is supposed to have full controller support and while you can use a controller to play this game, the controls feel off, like they didn't give much thought to it. The training parts of the game aren't any better, for some reason the game often reads the wrong buttons you are pressing, which makes the game even more frustrating because you can only do each training exercise once after so many fights. This doesn't make sense, we all know boxers aren't limited to the gym, we also know that they don't spend all day in the ring either. It feels like this game was designed behind a free to play model and they kind of just stuck with that. When I looked it up, that is absolutely true. The mobile version of this game only allows you to train so many times an hour or so, after which it's locked behind a pay wall. Character customization sucks, plain and simple - the reason being, there really isn't any. The game forces you to take on the persona of a small handful of fighters, you don't get to design your own. After which, you have to earn money in order to unlock new hair styles, styles of clothes and more. This wouldn't bother me so much if the initial character creation would allow me to actually design my own character.The difficultly ramps up at a ridiculous rate very early on. I was having fun playing the game and then suddenly, every fighter I started facing is built like a brick house, taking almost no damage and just destroying. I don't know if this is another result of their free to play model from the mobile edition, but I wouldn't be surprised.Sloppy, lazy, unfun, these are a few words to describe this game. It's not worth the $5.00 they are asking for this game, they should have just stuck with the free to play model they used on mobile devices.

Dodge is the same button as block, press to dodge (i.e. tap spam) and hold to block (i.e. wtf i pressed dodge not block... oh you gotta tap spam to dodge). Took me about 30 matches before i figured out how dodging worked. Even after I figured it out, it's not interactive. You dont dodge incoming blows, you predict them before any form of movement has ensued. Apparently this is a mobile app port, makes sense as playing on PC you can't react to anything in real time as i explained above. Its like a dance simulator except minus the visual cue's. If you react while a punch is being thrown its too late. You need to react before the punch is being thrown, like some form of anticipatory foreplay. This made me really sad as it removed all tactical gameplay. Gameplay:So playing through single player, you will notice STATS MEAN EVERYTHING. There are 3 main stats (ikr way to many to manage :P) Strength ((how much damage you do, opponents strength stat affects this) ie. 100% strength will do way more damage vs 68% strength than 92%) Stamina ((how quickly you gas out) doesn't really affect ♥♥♥♥ as even with max stamina vs low stamina you can only throw 3-4 punches before being gassed, it only really affects recovery speed in a high vs low stat (like strength as above)) and speed (who hits first) this doesnt really affect much either as i will explain later. Doesnt matter who hits 1st unless its against high level bots who can dodge like it has its own button :PFor instance you can have better Stamina and speed yet be losing by 3 points of strength, the person you are fighting will hit you and do 3 to 6 times as much damage (ie. 10 vs 30 or 60 damage). even though you are hitting 1st and more times.Punching doesn't involve any tactics either, as there is a generic high block and no real dodge function. So if you both swing both will hit (depending on punch choice), then it comes down to stamina or strength. i.e. Who can punch for longer or who hits harder. So if you have more speed and stamina you can do 1 more hit at less damage against someone who does more damage in less hits with strength i.e. as above ^ So playing through all the single player if you just level up before proceeding you can come out and 1st round KO everyone by just swinging then block recover stamina and swing (rinse and repeat) Character development: As stated stats progession is the main point of the game. If you try to play through the game and do the minigames every 5 matches you will have a bad time. Mainly because the minigames are horrible. You are better off just restarting the tournaments and buying all your stats with the cash winnings. Character creation: You can choose between about 8 premade characters and where you are from and your name. Def next level for a mobile 99 cent app port.Multiplayer: finished the game, decided to try multiplayer got some poor guy without 100% stats. Noticed a lot of lag and blackscreen between the knockdown screens i.e. 3-4 seconds. Also noticed a lot of delay, so im guessing matchmaking isnt done on ping. All in All: Wasn't impressed, the game offered no challenge and when it did (i.e. understats vs higher levels) the lack of an effective counter (i.e. dodge) really made it a pushing isht uphill problem. I actually like playing fightnight against way OP opponents as you could still dodge and outskill them, This game offers none of that depth. Its a 3d SNES port of mike tysons punchout.

												Real Boxing is a solid game marred by a few problems. The announcer is hilariously obnoxious. I really wish there was more and better boxer customization. There is no real variation in frame or facial structure. I can't play a slick, wiry bantamweight that looks like Rigondeaux - I have to look like competition-fit Kai Greene, with my choice of gear, facial features, and skin colour. You'd think that with how much variation there is in the build, height, and reach of boxers, it would at least be addressed in the game. But nope, every boxer uses the same re-skinned model.Graphical gripes aside, when I actually play it as I believe it was intended, Real Boxing is such a fun game. There are many elements to the strategy of boxing that they successfully incorporated game mechanics for. If you choose, every fight can be a chess match, with specific punches chosen to counter whatever they throw, fun and rewarding micro with timing headslips, and a range system that ends up modeling boxing footwork fairly well.Unfortunately, aspects of the game are broken -the stamina system and the stun / combo mechanic. These mechanics are supposed to reward skilled play; ideally you go in to trade 3 or 4 accurate and carefully chosen punches, then cover up and get back out of range. Unfortunately it is vastly more efficient to select the right perks and run forward while repeatedly jabbing your opponent to unconsciousness. Run at them, jab the guard until it breaks, jab them while they're stunned. Rinse, repeat. Boring.There is multiplayer and I have not yet dared. Who knows though, maybe amist all the cheese and jab spam, something resembling Real Boxing might happen.

Its decent enough, when you start, but then income the problems.When you start, you have about the same stats than your opponents. Your punches look and seem powerful, they do damage, though you can only hit 2-3 times since you will drain all your stamina, you have to wait to fill it again (few seconds without receiving hits or dodging a punch). You cannot train whenever you want or have cash for it, this only happens every few fightsand you can only train once per stat. 												“Real Boxing” is a surprisingly fun action-boxing game. I’ve never played “Fight Night” (I don’t own a console), but I’ve played many others over the years (all the way back to Atari 2600 boxing!). From my perspective, “Real Boxing” is the real deal, a legitimate boxing game that’s exciting and involving.If you’re a boxing purist like myself, however, you will notice some missing elements of actual boxing, and some aspects are quite unrealistic. I’ll list the CONS of the game first:CONS:-  no body attacks. That is, no punches at all to the midsection (stomach, below the belt, etc.) This is an entirely head-hunting game.- the controls are a bit awkward, no matter which option you choose (keyboard/mouse, joystick, etc.)  It will take some getting used to.- Opponents all fight in the same style, with only their stats (strength, stamina, and speed) making the difference in difficulty.-  the “clinching” system is frustrating and unrealistic. It’s a button-mashing exercise that can last the entire round! No ref will break it up. And usually, you will lose the clinch game against the computer opponent.- There’s no three-knockdown rule. I’ve battered opponents who’ve gotten up from knockdowns five times in one round!- Once you’ve won all three champoinship tournaments, there’s little incentive to keep playing the single player mode. You've beaten the game.- In multiplayer mode, you’ll get massacred by other players online!!!PROS: -  The action is fast-paced, tense, and suitably tactical. Keep your guard up! Jab, stick, and move!- The graphics are quite good. Not “Fight Night,” but still very attractive and well-animated.- You feel like you’re boxing! (Once you get past the “no body shots” limitation). - The training mini-games are effective, if a little frustrating at times. - You can't just blast through the game without building up you're stats over time. You will have to take on some lesser "quick fight" opponents to gain enough ring experience (and stats). Otherwise, "career" opponents will demolish you.Overall, this is a very fun (if a bit limited) boxing game. As many others have said, it isn’t “Fight Night,” but for the price, you’ll get your money’s worth out of this game, especially if you get it on sale or in a bundle.

												More a brawler than a boxing sim, this is no Fight Night, but given the woeful lack of PC boxing games, I'll take it. My only real fault with the game is it's clunky as crap sometimes. You can dodge an incoming punch, but the movement is sometimes too clunky for you to move in and counter in time. It's interesting though, the fewer rounds you set it to play as, the more damage you'll do. My first match I set to 15 rounds, and I ended up going the distance without getting the opponent's health bar down halfway. Set it to three hours, however, and you'll get two KOs per round easily. For the best balance of realism and arcade brawler I guess go with ten rounds.Minigames to level up your boxer are repetitive but more difficulty is added to these too as you go through the escalating boxing tournaments, which was a pleasant surprise that caught me off-guard. Sadly, these involve not just the buttons but the analogue sticks, and I often screwed up because I find it difficult to judge an angle to aim the stick at, so when it wanted the right stick to go up to the right at 45 degrees, I often missed it by going too far 90 degrees, or vice versa, which was frustrating and felt like a cheap fail.In lieu of more polished boxing sim alternatives this will serve well enough, but it could use a bit of polish. More variety in unlocks wouldn't go amiss either, the gear and especially the hair and stuff is far too limited, and you stand a good chance of fighting a clone of yourself, which is amusing but kinda weird :P
